title: How to Stage Your House for Selling

steps.headline: Clean the entire home thoroughly.
steps.description: Potential buyers will be turned off of your home if it is smelly or dirty. The idea when staging your home is to make it look as though it were a model home set up only for their viewing. This means that it must be squeaky clean! This will require a deep scrub of the bathroom! You don’t want to have any mold or soap scum in the tub, no rings in the toilet, and no toothpaste stuck in the sink. Don’t forget to do the same in the kitchen. All the counters should be wiped down so there are no crumbs or stains, all the dishes should be clean and put away. Make the beds up neatly. It’s even better if fresh sheets are put on for days when viewings are scheduled. Try to choose sheets and bed covers that are neutral in color, and that match well with the decor of the room. Wash the windows! It may seem like a minor detail, but having bright shiny windows inside and out will really improve the appearance of your home.

steps.headline: Pack personal things away.
steps.description: Although you might still be living in the home while you are trying to sell it, you want to make the house look as impersonal as possible. Therefore, you should pack away any personal photos, books, movies, etc. You can pack these in bubble wrap, and put them in boxes so that they are ready to go when you move out. However, make sure that you store these boxes somewhere out of site, such as in the attic. If you don't have adequate storage space, consider renting a storage unit. Whatever you do, don't have boxes lying around your home where potential buyers might see them.

steps.headline: Remove clutter from your home.
steps.description: It’s quite normal that, after years of living in a home, there will be clutter. However, you want prospective buyers to imagine themselves living in the home, so it’s best if you can make everything open, and clutter free. This way, they can imagine their own things in the home instead of yours. This may require some serious cleaning or packing! If you are a bit messy, it may just mean putting your clothes neatly away in a closet, or it may mean that you will have to pack away a large majority of your belongings, leaving only the minimum things you need to live in the home. In the kitchen and bathroom, have all of your personal items stored off the counter. For example, take your toothbrush and toothpaste and put them in the cabinet, or at least hide them while people are viewing the home. Be aware that viewers are very likely to open drawers, cabinets, and cupboards. Thus, you can’t simply shove everything in a closet, and hope they don’t notice. Properly staging your home will require you to do some serious cleaning.

steps.headline: Repaint the walls.
steps.description: Give your walls a fresh coat of paint in a neutral color. You don’t know who will be looking at your home or what their tastes will be. Having neutral walls will allow visitors to imagine the home in their own way. This will be more difficult to do if the walls are very bold. If you don’t want to do this yourself, and ff you can afford it, it may be worth hiring professional painters to do the job.

steps.headline: Set the table.
steps.description: If you have nice china and silverware, use these to set your dining room table. You want the table to be arranged nicely, so adding something like candles, fresh flowers, and cloth napkins in coordinating colors will really impress potential buyers. If you have several days or weeks of viewings set up, make sure that you do a quick dusting of the table each day that you have a viewing. This way, it will always look freshly set.

steps.headline: Turn on the lights.
steps.description: You want your home to appear bright, warm, and welcoming. If it is very dark, it is unlikely that viewers will feel this way. Therefore, when there are viewings scheduled, you should turn on at least one light in each room. If you have a room that is quite dark even with the light on, consider adding a lamp or two to brighten things up. This will help the home feel more cozy.

steps.headline: Add art to the walls.
steps.description: While you should not have personal photos or overly specific pictures on the wall, a few paintings of landscapes or abstract pictures will brighten up the room. Be sure to fix any holes in the wall once you move out! If you have a small room, you could also hang a decorative mirror instead of art. This has the added advantage of making the room appear larger. Avoid choosing art that may offend someone, while it is hard to say what this might be, it is generally safest to stick to landscape art and/or abstract art. It may seem silly, but it also might make a potential buyer choose to search elsewhere. EXPERT TIP																															Hannah Park																Real Estate Agent								Hannah Park is a Licensed Real Estate Agent operating in Los Angeles, California and is a part of Keller Williams, Larchmont. She received her Real Estate Certification in 2018 from the California Bureau of Real Estate, and now specializes as a Buyer's Agent and Listing Agent. Hannah Park			Real Estate Agent				Keep your likely buyer in mind as you decorate. Staging a home to sell involves assessing what kind of people are likely to move to that neighborhood. If, for example, it's a very family-friendly neighborhood, you might have a room that's kid-friendly. If you want a younger home buyer, you would stage the home with things that would attract vibrant, young clients.

steps.headline: Add a few color pops to each room.
steps.description: These colors should coordinate with any themes in the art you have added. For example, you can add one or two colorful throw pillows, or a nice blanket on the back of the couch. You could also add a fresh vase of colorful flowers to the coffee table. Choose just one or two bright objects to add. Generally, the room should be as neutral as possible, with just one or two splashes of color. Limiting the color splashes will make the room a bit more interesting, but still neutral enough for potential buyers to utilize their own imagination.

steps.headline: Remove furniture that doesn’t fit well into a space.
steps.description: If you have crammed your living room full of mismatched recliners and an old love seat, it’s time to remove a few. Choose one or two pieces of furniture that fit well with the other changes you have made, and that make the room look comfortable, but not cramped. For example, in a normal sized living room, you might place a medium-sized couch with a coffee table, a TV, and possibly a nice sitting chair. Human beings naturally prefer symmetry. Thus, it might be good to try to arrange your living room in the same way. For example, you could arrange two sofas so that they face each other, and place a coffee table in between. You can do the same thing if you have matching chairs. If you have a very large living room, you may need to break up the space a bit. You can still follow the idea of keeping the room symmetrical by making one part of the room a sitting area with some matching chairs and/or sofas, and making another part of the room a writing area by placing a desk with a chair and some fresh flowers. You can also use a large sectional couch to take up some of the space.

steps.headline: Enhance curb appeal.
steps.description: What the outside of your home looks like is just as important as what the inside looks like. Make sure the lawn is neat and mowed, trim any unruly hedges, make sure toys are cleaned up, and consider giving your home a fresh coat of paint, if it is needed. Plant some bright, colorful flowers (if the season is appropriate), hang some house numbers that are elegant and easy to read. If you have a sidewalk, you should scrub it or use a pressure washer to make sure there are no stains. You should also make sure your porch, stoop, or front entryway looks inviting. Place a clean doormat, and a couple of chairs or a rocking chair, if you have the space. Turn your porch light on in the evenings, as potential buyers may decide to make a spontaneous drive-by. You can also place solar lights, which are powered by the sun during the day and turn on during the night, along your walk way, which will look nice, and also illuminate the path.

steps.headline: Ask your real estate agent to inspect your work.
steps.description: If you have hired a real estate agent, ask them to give you feedback on what you've done. They are professionals, so they will likely have good experience with what works, and what doesn't.

steps.headline: Figure out whether or not you can afford a home stager.
steps.description: The costs of hiring one can be relatively high depending on a number of factors, such as the size of your home, the state of your home, and where you live. Although it might be expensive, if you can afford it, this cost may be made up for in the selling price. Especially if you can't or are unwilling to do the work yourself. EXPERT TIP	Every home stager has a different fee, which depends on their experience and expertise, as well as the cost of materials. Hannah Park					Real Estate Agent								Hannah Park is a Licensed Real Estate Agent operating in Los Angeles, California and is a part of Keller Williams, Larchmont. She received her Real Estate Certification in 2018 from the California Bureau of Real Estate, and now specializes as a Buyer's Agent and Listing Agent. Hannah ParkReal Estate Agent

steps.headline: Consider opting for a consultation only.
steps.description: If a professional staging is out of your budget, consider asking for a consultation only. Many professional stagers will give you a free consultation anyway, but some are also willing to simply advise you on the things that you should change before showing your home for a more minimal cost. If you opt for this, be honest with the stager. Don’t take advantage of them by having them come by for a first consultation and then ignoring their calls and emails after they’ve given you advice.

steps.headline: Look at portfolios.
steps.description: Most professionals will have either physical or on-line portfolios, which will allow you to see some of their past work. Everyone has a different style, and you may have something different in mind than what a particular stager can offer.

steps.headline: Ask for references.
steps.description: Most experienced stagers will be happy to offer your references. However, remember that they would not recommend a reference if they weren’t sure that it would be a positive reference. Therefore, you should also search online for the name and city of this stager (or their company name) to read other reviews. If you can’t find them online, call around to some local real estate agencies to see if they have heard anything about this stager. Don’t forget to ask your personal realtor, if you have one.

steps.headline: Interview more than one candidate.
steps.description: Don’t just go with the first option. Instead, choose several possible candidates, and interview them about their rates, time requirements, whether they will require you to buy new furniture, whether they will include the outside as well, etc. If your stagers know they are one of a few candidates, they may also offer you a better price. Make sure your chosen professional has knowledge of the real estate market. Being a good stager requires one to know trends in the real estate market, not just how to decorate nicely.

steps.headline: Create a contract.
steps.description: Most professionals will do this for you, but if your chosen professional doesn’t offer one, then draft an agreement in writing, which states when they will be finished, what services they will provide, what the cost will be, etc. It may be a bit awkward, but this will protect you from being taken advantage of.
